repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Here's a fix for #2764, and for the [question on Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/53744729/425458) that inspired it. When using an out place build with a `cythonize`-ed extension, before the path of any source file is used to generate the paths to the corresponding `.c` and `.o` files, the source file path is first cleaned up. This proceeds in two steps:

- `os.path.normpath(pth)` is called, which will resolve any `../` in the middle of the path, or bubble them over to the left side.

- If `pth` is a relative path, all leading `../` elements are then removed. If `pth` is absolute, then we don't need to both checking for any `../`.

This approach should allow for the use of src paths like `"../../../src/foo.pyx"` in `cythonize`-ed extensions, while still preserving enough path to prevent generated files from clobbering one another.

comment_data.body: Any reason you need to use numpy here? That makes the test fail (or requires it to be excluded) when numpy is not installed. Seems an unnecessary limitation to me.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,40 @@
+# Tests the out of place (ie with build_dir set) build when a src file is
+# "above" the setup.py (ie it's path begins with dots). 
+# For example, "../../../src/foo.pyx". See #2764 for details.
+
+cd a/b/c/d; PYTHON setup.py build_ext -b ../../pkg -t .
+PYTHON check_paths.py
+
+######## a/b/c/d/setup.py ########
+
+from distutils.core import setup
+from distutils.extension import Extension
+from Cython.Build import cythonize
+
+import numpy as np
+
+extensions = [
+    Extension(
+        'boolFunc',
+        ['../../../src/foo.pyx'],
+        include_dirs=[np.get_include()],

comment_data.body: The directory names here do not work on Windows.

comment_data.body:
Can you be a bit more specific about the potential issue? I am not a Windows native. I tried some commands out in a Wineskin:

```
md a
md b
md c
md d
cd a/b/c/d
```

and they seem to work fine. From the little bit of reading I just did, it seems like slash `/` is a valid path sep on Windows, you just can't use it at the beginning of paths in `cmd.exe`. Are you concerned about conflicts with the drive letters? 

The only other thing I could think of was that `md a/b/c/d` doesn't seem to be valid (but `md a\b\c\d` is). So is it a problem with making the dirs?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,40 @@

+

comment_data.body: Yeah, according to Appveyor, `cd a/b/c/d` does not work but needs to use `\`. Separate `cd a`, `cd b`, â€¦ commands would be an easy way to fix it, I guess.

commit.message: switched `;` to `&&` in an attempt at windows compatibility
fixed path normalization for above-src-build for windows

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: fixes #2764: sensibly normalizes src paths like "../../../src/foo.pyx" when using an out of place build directory
